doc.title: EPS Estimate Changes
doc.source_uri: 2025-09-02/J.P. Morgan Taiwan FTM 1 Sep 25J.P. Morgan Taiwan FTM 1 Sep 25_2025-09-02

passages.text: Greater China (Tingting Ge)- China: A narrowing fall in July industrial profits- Taiwan: IP ticked up, lifted by IC production; 3Q GDP growth forecast upgraded from \(- 2\%\) to \(0.5\% q / q\) saar- Next week: China PMIs; Hong Kong retail sales; Taiwan PMI, CPI
Dell and HPQ (covered by J.P. Morgan U.S. Equity Analyst Samik Chatterjee) reported Jul- Q earnings this week. The key implications for the Asian tech supply chain were:

Robust Al server demand on lifted Dell's Al server revenue guidance.Dell's Jul- Q Al server revenues came in at US \(8.2bn\) , stronger than company guidance at US \(7bn\) and market expectations. Server margins have tracked behind expectations due to higher GB200 mix and some one- off GB200 ramping costs, which was consistent with Wistron's feedback. Looking forward, management continues to see strong Al server demand across CSPs, enterprises, and sovereign Al and has booked US \(5.6bn\) in new orders. Dell expects an improving Al server margin on mix shift to enterprise and sovereign Al and improving GB200/300 yields. Overall, the company has now raised full year Al server revenue guidance to US \(20bn\) from previous US \(15bn+\) with \(50\% /50\%\) 1H/2H split. This underpins our research of incremental upside to Dell and Wistron's Al server revenues in 2H25 driven by new GB300 order wins. But the low Al server margin has negative implications for other Al server brand peers and Wistron as ODM partner.
Mega Holdings (Hmmmy S Huang) (2886 TT, N, PT NT\\$36.60) 1H25 results in line; weaker PPOP offset by lower credit costs

Mega's 1H25 results were largely in line with our expectations as weaker- than- expected PPOP was largely offset by lower credit costs and better earnings growth at Bills' finance and P&C insurance operations. We revise up our FY26E earnings by \(1\%\) to factor in lower credit costs and retain our Neutral rating with a new PT of NT\\$36.6 by moving forward our valuation base to Dec- 26.

Mega's 1H25 results were largely in line with our expectations as weaker- than- expected PPOP was largely offset by lower credit costs and better earnings growth at Bills' finance and P&C insurance operations. We revise up our FY26E earnings by \(1\%\) to factor in lower credit costs and retain our Neutral rating with a new PT of NT\\$36.6 by moving forward our valuation base to Dec- 26.
Silergy Corp (William Yang) (6415 TT, OW, PT NT\\$470.00)
2025 rev guided down on weaker 3Q25 outlook, but solid progress in auto and server to drive 2026 growth

On its 2Q25 earnings call, management guided down its 2025 revenue from the previous \(20\%\) YoY growth target, which we think was well expected, but its 3Q25 outlook is weaker than expected due to ongoing uncertainties in some segments, despite overall demand gradually bottoming out. The bright spot of the call was the company's automotive growth potential, which could be driven by a significant content increase and continued rising product adoption in both China and international customers. Also, its server business may start to see more meaningful contribution from 2026 with breakthroughs in ASIC customers/projects. Thus, we stay OW as we think investors will gradually shift focus to Silergy's longer-term outlook after reflecting on the softer near-term outlook.
Taishin Financial Holdings (Jemmy S Huang) (2887 TT, UW, PT NT \(14.4\) )

Taishin's 1H25 results were largely in line with our expectations as double- digit earnings growth at the banking operations was offset by weaker securities and life insurance operations. We revise up our earnings forecasts by \(55 / 149\%\) for FY25/26E to factor in the consolidation of Shinkong and reiterate our UW rating with a new PT of NT \(14.4\) to reflect the merger impact and moving forward our valuation base to Dec- 26.
GUC (Gokul Hariharan) (3443 TT, UW)
